_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Whatcom Co. Div. Of Emergency Mgmt.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ram consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures, as necessary, to perform their specific emergency response duties. 

The ERP includes a set of potential incidents that are used for emergency drills, including accidental release of toxic gases (ammonia), accidental release of flammable materials resulting in a fire and explosion, and accidental spill of hazardous materials on the ground within the refinery perimeter.  

The BP Cherry Point Refinery uses an Emergency Management Organization, known as the Incident Command System (ICS), to respond to and manage incidents.  The ICS has a hierarchical (i.e., chain-of-command) structure that places the highest responsibility on the Emergency Manager, who has the overall responsibility for the emergency.  The Emergency Manager delegates direct command responsibilities to the Incident Commander, who has the highest authority during an emergency.  The Emergency Manger is a liaison between the Incident Commander, the public, and the Company.  The next level of responsibility resides on four section chiefs: Command Chief, Operations Chief, Planning Chief, and Logistics/Finance Chief.  All section chiefs receive directions from the Incident Commander during an emergency.  Each position within the organization has specific assignmen

incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training for the change.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The refinery promptly and thoroughly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a reoccurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a reoccurrence, and forwards these results to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA re-validations.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  The audit team forwards its findings to refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all program EPA-RMP covered processes at the re

he equipment back into service, or a team will review equipment use and determine what actions are necessary to ensure its safe operation.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The BP Cherry Point Refinery incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when making repairs. The mechanical integrity program was developed and documented by the Engineering Authority and is updated by the Engineering Authority, as needed.


SAFE WORK PRACTICES

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these practices include: (1) electronic control of unit entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (4) a permit and procedure to control hot work activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a comprehensive system to manage process changes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls will not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to

ry personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEWS

The BP Cherry Point Refinery conducts a process startup safety review for any new facility or facility modifications that require a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  A safety review involves field verification of the construction and provides quality assurance by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The refinery has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training inspections and tests.  These inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the equipment functions as intended and is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified, employees correct the deficiency before placing t

completing this training, a new operator is paired with an experienced operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner, they can work independently.  In addition to initial training, all operators periodically receive refresher training to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every three years.  

All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.  A modern, up-to-date, fully programmable computer-driven simulator, with display panels identical to those used in the control room, is also available in the larger units for employees to practice unit operations.  The simulators are fully functional and can duplicate all unit characteristics, and can also be used to simulate proposed changes to determine whether safety parameters could be violated.


CONTRACTORS

The BP Cherry Point Refinery uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the refinery has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow the site safety rules, and (6) inform refinery personnel of any hazards that they encounter during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  In addition, the refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the contractor selection process.  Refine

l.  The refinery has several regulated flammables: isobutane, butane, pentane, propane, and flammable mixtures. Toxic substances common to refineries were evaluated: hydrogen sulfide, anhydrous ammonia, aqueous ammonia, sulfur dioxide, and mercaptans do not exceed their respective threshold quantities and therefore are not reported.

Unit #10 - Crude/Vacuum Unit

The Crude/Vacuum Unit consists of two processes.  The Crude Unit is the initial process unit in the refinery, and is designed to remove salt and sediment from raw crude oil then heat and fractionate the crude into finished and intermediate products.  The Vacuum Unit is designed to process crude tower bottoms in the vacuum diesel fractionator tower and the vacuum tower.  Negative pressure (i.e., a vacuum) is required to fractionate this heavy material without forming coke.  The Crude Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 74,000 pounds (lbs). 

Unit #11 - #1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit

The #1 Reformer/Naphtha Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) Unit consists of two processes.  The purpose of the #1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit is to convert the low-octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracker units into a stabilized high-octane blending stock.  This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.  The Naphtha HDS Unit is designed to treat the feedstock for the #1 Reformer.  Treatment is necessary to prevent contamination and plugging of the Reformer catalyst.  The #1 Reformer/Naphtha HDS Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 540,000 lbs.  

Unit #12 - Coker

The Coker is a thermal cracking unit designed to receive and process vacuum residuum from the Crude Unit, which is separated into a sweet dry gas, debutanized or depropanized gasoline, coker stove oil, l

at Cherry Point will be via either hazard and operability studies (HAZOPs) or What-If Checklist studies.  The HAZOP and What-If Checklist processes are based on the principle that a team approach to hazard analysis will identify more problems than when individuals work separately and combine results.  The PHA team is comprised of individuals with varying backgrounds and expertise brought together to thoroughly review the process hazards through collective brainstorming.

The team's findings are forwarded to local management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation measures is tracked until complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, tracked to completion, and retained.
To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted every five years.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.


OPERATING PROCEDURES

The BP Cherry Point Refinery maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Through the management of change process, these procedures are kept current and accurately maintained.  

This information is readily available to operators in the process units and for other personnel to use, as necessary, to perform their job tasks safely.


TRAINING

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in process operation.  

New employees receive basic training in refinery operations.  After successfully

afety Team, Refinery Safety Committee, and Process Safety Committee.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The BP Cherry Point Refinery maintains a variety of technical documents that help ensure safe facility operation.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining and updating process safety information.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets.  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns.  For specific process areas, the refinery has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters.  The refinery ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems.

The refinery also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes, to ensure that safety features are not compromised.


PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The BP Cherry Point Refinery has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) performed

tion Unit (#1 DHDS) is designed to remove impurities from coker stove oil and gas oil and to produce finished stove oil and diesel.  The #1 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit (#1 DHDS) is Program 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 150,000 lbs.

                                                                                                                                                                                  
GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the BP Cherry Point Refinery.  Because processes at the refinery that are subject to the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION 
BP Cherry Point employees have always been encouraged to be involved in all aspects of operating this facility.  Through the years an open working relationship has been maintained between employer and employee.  Employee(s) includes BP and Contractor personnel unless otherwise stated; BP employee indicates BP only. Employee Participation is typically accomplished in all 14 elements through four basic approaches:

By direct participation of interested employees, on both an assigned and voluntary basis, based on knowledge and availability, on PHA review teams, as Safety Representatives, on safety committees, etc.

By interaction with affected employees using a variety of methods such as natural work teams, group safety meetings, safety log/near miss book entries, process safety audits, safety audits, and feedback at annual safety training, and 

By addressing concerns voiced to management pertaining to an element of the overall process safety management program, or other safety related issues, and

By inquiries to the Process S

3 because of regulated flammable mixture and liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 100,000 lbs.

Unit #27 - #3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit (#3 DHDS)

The #3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit (#3 DHDS) is designed to process 12,300 BPD of light coker gas oil and 14,600 BPD of diesel feed and to operate at 750 psig. As currently designed, the unit will process light coker gas oil feed from the Coker Unit, straight run diesel feeds from the crude unit and vacuum diesel fractionator, and tallow. Renewable diesel is being produced by the co-processing of the tallow with existing feeds into #3 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit. The #3 DHDS process combines hydrogen with the straight run diesel feeds, and processes them in a high pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst. The reaction produces hydrogen sulfide, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed from the process through amine scrubbing. The amine hydrogen sulfide mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant and processed into molten sulfur. The unit consumes 12.8 million standard cubic feet per day of 1,226 pounds per square inch gauge hydrogen and is designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 parts per million (ppm) to less than 15 ppm. The #3 DHDS Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixture and liquids. The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 130,000 lbs.


Unit #36/37 - Gasoline Blender & LPG Loading

The Gasoline Blender Unit involves blending finished fuels and shipping them to the Olympic pipeline.  The Propane/Butane Loading Unit involves the storage and shipment of LPG by rail and truck.  The Gasoline Blender and Propane/Butane Loading Units are Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable liquids stored in these units is 7,400,000 lbs.

Unit #13 - #1 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit (#1 DHDS)

The #1 Diesel Hydrodesulfuriza

ipt and shipping facilities.  The Tank Farm is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable liquids.  The calculated weight of the flammable liquids stored in this unit is 290,000,000 lbs.

Unit #45 - Isomerization Unit

The Isomerization Unit #45 processes light naphtha streams to remove sulfur and nitrogen contaminates, saturate olefins, and benzene, and provides a moderate- to high-octane gasoline component as the final product.  The Isomerization Unit is fed untreated material from the Crude Unit, cracked stocks from the Coker Unit, and a low-sulfur, benzene-rich material from the Reformer Unit.  The final isomerate product is free of benzene and low in sulfur.  The Isomerization Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 1,300,000 lbs.

Unit #26 - #2 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization Unit (#2 DHDS)

The #2 Diesel Hydrodesulfurization (#2 DHDS) is designed to process 18,000 barrels per day of diesel feed and to operate at 850 pounds per square inch gauge.  The design basis provides for a future case where the unit can process cracked feedstocks under more severe conditions, although numerous modifications still need to be made to accomplish this.  As currently designed, the unit processes straight-run diesel feeds from the crude unit.  The #2 DHDS process combines hydrogen with straight-run diesel feeds and processes them in a high-pressure reactor filled with specialty catalyst.  The reaction produces hydrogen sulfide, which is then separated from the diesel stream and removed from the process through amine scrubbing.  The amine hydrogen sulfide mixture is recycled to the sulfur recovery plant and processed into molten sulfur.  The unit consumes 6 to 7 million standard cubic feet per day of 220 pounds per square inch gauge hydrogen and is designed to reduce the sulfur in the diesel from 6,800 parts per million (ppm) to less than 15 ppm.  The #2 DHDS Unit is Program Level

ight coker gas oil, heavy coker gas oil, and coke.  The Coker is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 35,000 lbs. 

Unit #15 - Hydrocracker

The Hydrocracker is a combined hydrogenation and catalytic cracking process designed to convert low-grade gas oils to high-quality gasoline and middle distillate products with a net consumption of hydrogen.  The Hydrocracker is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 130,000 lbs.  

Unit #16/#22 - Light Ends Unit/LPG

The Light Ends Unit #16 is designed to process feed streams containing C5s and lighter hydrocarbons (pentane C5, butane C4, propane C3, ethane C2, and methane C1) and to produce pentane, isobutane, normal butane, and mixed butane for storage and handling.  It also produces fuel gas, Hydrogen Plant feed, or liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) feed for Unit #22.  The Light Ends Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 1,600,000 lbs.

The LPG Unit #22 processes light end absorber release gas and produces fuel gas and propane.  The LPG Unit is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 17,000 lbs.


Unit #21 - #2 Reformer

The purpose of the #2 Reformer is to convert the low-octane gasoline feed fractions from the Naphtha HDS and Hydrocracking units into stabilized high-octane blending stock.  This is accomplished through the use of catalyst under high temperatures and a hydrogen atmosphere.  The #2 Reformer is Program Level 3 because of regulated flammable mixtures.  The calculated weight of the flammable mixtures stored in this unit is 54,000 lbs.

 
Unit #33 - Tank Farm

The Tank Farm Unit stores the process units' feed and products.  It also contains pipeline rece
